text: Summarize (Orchestrating the Discussion)
Solutions and Strategies

Have students display their posters. Use a Gallery Walk for students to see how other students put together their groups. Have students use sticky notes to put questions and comments on other students’ posters.
Making the Mathematics Explicit
Discuss the posters from the Gallery Walk that had the most questions.
Suggested questions

• How did you decide what to group together in the Initial Challenge? (Answers will vary.)
  • How did you know if a card represented a linear relationship? (Answers will vary. Bring out how the rate of change shows up in a table, graph, context, equation.)
  • How did you find a rate of change for a linear card? (Answers will vary.)
  • How did you find the y-intercept for a linear card? (Answers will vary.)
  • How did you find groups for the cards that weren’t linear? (Answers will vary. Bring out how students were able to “tell the story” even when it wasn’t a constant rate of change. For example, with Graph D students can recognize that it isn’t linear because it isn’t a straight line. They can find values for the points (1, 1); (2,2); (3,4). This will match with Table T and context M with the trivia game.)
  • Look at all the cards. Which cards represented a positive rate of change/slope? (Graph B, Graph C, Equation G, Equation I, Equation J, Context K, Context N, Context P, Table T, Table U, Table V)
  • Look at all the cards. Which cards represent proportional relationships? (Graph C, Equation J, Context K, Graph E)
  • How did you decide which equations were equivalent in What If Situation A? (Answers will vary)
Discuss those equations that were most troublesome for your class. An example from one classroom:
Teacher: I heard a lot of conversations about Equation 9: 3x + 2 = 14 + x. How did you decide if a card was equivalent to it?
Tasha: That one stumped us for a while. We decided to draw it as rubas and pouches to help us make some sense of it. That is when we found that it matched with equation card 16.
Teacher: Do others agree with Tasha’s group? (heads nod) Were there other cards that matched with Equations 9 and 16?

Robert: At first we didn’t think so and then we decide to try and “crack the code” like we did before with rubas and pouches. When we crossed off the 1 pouch that each side had in common and the two coins you end up with 2 pouches equals 12 coins. That was 2X = 12.
Tasha: Oh my gosh! You are right! I didn’t see that. So, then if you divide up the coins into the two pouches there would be 6 in each pouch and that is the x = 6 card.
To extend the conversation, pick one set and describe a context that could be represented by this set of equations.
Now What Do Students Know
Ask students to reflect on the discussion and answer the Now What Do You Know questions.
See answers to the Problem for more information about the strategies and embedded mathematics.
Reflecting on Student Learning
Use the following questions to assess student understanding at the end of the lesson.
• What evidence do I have that students understand the Now What Do You Know questions?

1. Where did my students get stuck?
  2. What strategies did they use?
  3. What breakthroughs did my students have today?

• How will I use this to plan for tomorrow? For the next time I teach this lesson?
  • Where will I have the opportunity to reinforce these ideas as I continue through this Unit? The next Unit?
